title: I tried to help a toxic player today. Here is how it went.

replies.body: They really do need a load in tip that says "1 report flags a player for a particular game. Extra reports do not matter and begging for them is considered toxic."

Except you're both wrong.. honestly I was going to write a whole thing about how I know from experience and it should be obvious by now with the amount of people that came foward claiming this. But I'll just say this, believe what you want. Riot reps are here to keep order and peace, they're not going to tell you their system is flawed and biased. They're happy they even have a system at all to deal with how toxic the community is. They're not going to tell you its flawed. And yes expect to see 5-10 downvotes on my comments by their mods and fake accounts. Its the Truth.

Well, just based on what's in the post, OP isn't wrong. [It clearly states in the Riot Punishment FAQ that asking for reports is considered player harassment. ](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/207489286-Instant-Feedback-System-FAQ-) If you disagree with the system, that's cool, but he's factually correct in telling Nunu that what he's doing is reportable and punishable.
so even if i say to report a legit troll or toxic guy then i may get punished for it?gr8 system if u ask me

One report has the same value as _nine_, so there isn't a valid reason to even tell someone you're reporting them. Saying "I'm going to report you" isn't easily punished on it's own but saying "Everyone report Vel'Koz super toxic gg his account" is clear player harassment.

 The reason it's considered player harassment is because it accomplishes nothing in game. Telling someone you're going to report them or asking for reports is just another way of trying to get people to jump on the bandwagon of bashing the player. 

 I think Riot needs to make this point more clear, but I think the system is fine and it's totally fair for this to be considered harassment.

It really is a wonderful thing to have such an amazingly accepting community that does its utmost to protect the tender feelings of trolls while throwing the people actually having their games ruined by trolls under the bus.

I appreciate the sarcasm, but that rule is there mainly to protect players who perform poorly in game and get bashed for it.

>"Lucian garbage report for feeding"
>"Vlad handing out first blood report"
>"Yeah can we all report Kai'sa? She's toxic scum"

 All _should_ be reportable based on what I said above about it promoting a bandwagon affect. 

 Even if it's directed towards someone who is trolling or who is negative, that doesn't change the fact that you're trying to rally others to gang up on other player. Just because that person is griefing doesn't give you a right to stoop to their level as well.

You might want to realize that the pervasive toxicity in this game does not come out of nowhere. It's often born out of frustration with the fact that Riot consistently fails to do anything about people who intentionally ruin matches because it's "hard to prove".

I played League for something like five years before recently deciding to quit, and throughout those years, I maintained a mentality of "just ignore them, report them, they'll be dealt with". But you know what? *They weren't.* No other game has such a severe trolling problem as League.

When I sit down to play League, that's so I can wind down after a day of work, not to have 30-40 minutes of my free time stolen by some fucking bastard whom Riot refuses to punish for it. And when you know that the *worst* consequence they will ever suffer is having some frustration vented on them, you stop giving a damn about whether Daddy Riot tells you not to be mean.

>You might want to realize that the pervasive toxicity in this game does not come out of nowhere. It's often born out of frustration with the fact that Riot consistently fails to do anything about people who intentionally ruin matches because it's "hard to prove".

 Even so, toxicity is never justified. The only way a community can grow is if people stop fighting fire with fire. Player's also don't have the right to become overly frustrated to the point where they become toxic. It's not productive, they're directly feeding into the problem, and as Illabethe said, I haven't seen a game be _more_ strict in the past 5-10 years. 

>I maintained a mentality of "just ignore them, report them, they'll be dealt with". But you know what? They weren't. 

 You don't know that.

 Not only is the IFS message very inconsistent (so punishments being doled out can almost never be confirmed) but you're also unaware of what punishment tier someone is on. You wouldn't be able to look at a match history and see who got punished because that's their final straw, every other case is just subjective. 

Don't try to focus on this aspect so much, if you consistently report people who deserve it, they will get punished. 


 I've been permanently banned before, the system definitely works considering I didn't use any zero tolerance language or int any games. I was your average run of the mill flamey boi and got punished for it. 

>No other game has such a severe trolling problem as League.

 That's because no other game is as large as League. Again, as Illabethe said, there hasn't been a game more punishing of trolls in a long, long time. 

>not to have 30-40 minutes of my free time stolen by some fucking bastard whom Riot refuses to punish for it. And when you know that the worstconsequence they will ever suffer is having some frustration vented on them, you stop giving a damn about whether Daddy Riot tells you not to be mean.

 Again, you don't have any way of knowing who does and doesn't get punished. If you want to feed into the problem and stoop to their level, eventually you're going to get punished too. Don't stoop to their level and don't fight fire with fire.

> Even so, toxicity is never justified. The only way a community can grow is if people stop fighting fire with fire. 

...or if Riot finally starts taking measures to eliminate the source of the problems, rather than punishing those who become symptoms.

>Player's also don't have the right to become overly frustrated to the point where they become toxic. 

There is a fancy little expression for what you're doing there. What was it again? Ah yes, *victim blaming*.

>It's not productive, they're directly feeding into the problem, and as Illabethe said, I haven't seen a game be more strict in the past 5-10 years. 

Strict on language, perhaps. Certainly not strict on behavior.

>Not only is the IFS message very inconsistent (so punishments being doled out can almost never be confirmed) but you're also unaware of what punishment tier someone is on. You wouldn't be able to look at a match history and see who got punished because that's their final straw, every other case is just subjective. 

You see, I find it highly unlikely that people who don't otherwise troll just spontaneously turn into trolls in my matches. Going by that, and the relatively high frequency at which I encounter trolls, it's safe to say that they have trolled others in the past as well.

>That's because no other game is as large as League. Again, as Illabethe said, there hasn't been a game more punishing of trolls in a long, long time. 

Oh no no no. Punishing of *flamers*, not of trolls.

>Again, you don't have any way of knowing who does and doesn't get punished. If you want to feed into the problem and stoop to their level, eventually you're going to get punished too. Don't stoop to their level and don't fight fire with fire.

I mean, I have. Why do you think I'm here? To support those who, like me, feel that the system in its current state is intolerably ass-backwards.
(Mind you, I didn't stick around long enough to get banned. I decided that I will not tolerate the unfair treatment Riot chose to subject me to, and moved on to another MOBA that has far less of a trolling issue instead.)

>There is a fancy little expression for what you're doing there. What was it again? Ah yes, victim blaming.

 Okay, that's not victim blaming. Victim implies that the person has done no wrong in the situation, but they have in this one. Both parties have. Both parties are guilty of the same crime.

 Both people stooped to the same level, both parties flamed, both parties should get punished. If you disagree with that, that's fine, but it's a fair system and it enforces positive mentalities. 

>Certainly not strict on behavior. / Oh no no no. Punishing of flamers, not of trolls.

 Riot is strict on behavior (as evidenced again by the fact that I was permabanned for poor behavior) and they do ban players who intentionally feed games. If you're arguing that it's not strict enough, that's a valid complaint but right now I think it's fine. Both of those are just our opinions. 

> You see, I find it highly unlikely that people who don't otherwise troll just spontaneously turn into trolls in my matches. 

Yes, that is a valid point, but as I said you have no way of knowing who is and isn't getting punished for the reasons listed above. 


>I decided that I will not tolerate the unfair treatment Riot chose to subject me to, 

 I see this argument come up _a lot_ and it's possibly the most contradictory point someone could make. The system _is_ fair by punishing you for stooping to their level. It wouldn't be right for you to be just as aggressive as the person next to you, but because they started it, that justifies it? 

 No. Punishment systems shouldn't and don't work that way.

> Okay, that's not victim blaming. Victim implies that the person has done no wrong in the situation, but they have in this one. Both parties have. Both parties are guilty of the same crime.
Both people stooped to the same level, both parties flamed, both parties should get punished. If you disagree with that, that's fine, but it's a fair system and it enforces positive mentalities. 

Except what I'm talking about here is not flamer vs. flamer. It's troll vs. ordinary player lashing out at the troll.

>Riot is strict on behavior (as evidenced again by the fact that I was permabanned for poor behavior) and they do ban players who intentionally feed games. If you're arguing that it's not strict enough, that's a valid complaint but right now I think it's fine. Both of those are just our opinions. 

When I say "behavior", I'm referring to actions. In fact, my core argument is that Riot is too strict on words and too lenient on actions.

>Yes, that is a valid point, but as I said you have no way of knowing who is and isn't getting punished for the reasons listed above. 

If they are trolling in my match, and didn't *start* trolling in my match, that means they have trolled others before and weren't punished for it.

>I see this argument come up a lot and it's possibly the most contradictory point someone could make. The system is fair by punishing you for stooping to their level. It wouldn't be right for you to be just as aggressive as the person next to you, but because they started it, that justifies it? 

No, as I said, it's unfair because it punishes flaming harshly and trolling not at all unless it's of the most obvious kind.

>Except what I'm talking about here is not flamer vs. flamer. It's troll vs. ordinary player lashing out at the troll.

 The problem here is that there is no difference between those types of players. Lashing out at someone _is_ stooping to their level and becoming a flamer. You need to be able to accept that.

That's flat-out wrong.
There is a HUGE difference between someone who rages at someone else at the drop of a hat, and someone who snaps when someone is doing their absolute best to make them miserable.
It's like someone spits on you, kicks you, shits on you, kills your mother, and you get punished because you called them a bad word.
It absolutely *isn't* the same, and lumping them in with each other is one of the gravest shortcomings of the current system (second only to its inability to punish trolls, that is).

Self control goes a long way. I'm more sympathetic to someone who may snap after being berated for multiple games, but at the end of the day, a player who inherently flames is the same as someone who flames when provoked. 

 The action is punishable and should be regardless of who does it.

I know that's a popular way of looking at it..... but I want to point something out:

I've haven't seen a game excise as much punitive action against "how you chat" since..... 2008.

In other words, you're asking for more punishment of trolls....... yet no other game has really punished EITHER as much.

Trolls probably wouldn't be as pervasive if it wasn't so fun to bait the chat toxicity...... and sometimes what we call trolls legitimately ARE just bad players or just having a one off bad game. Sometimes they are just reacting to your attitude in a low elo and reckoning, " Hey. I'm already in Bronze, and I don't have to put up with this verbal abuse. So I'm going to throw this game."

It also wouldn't surprise me if the most toxic players are also correlated with having a home life and children. You have no idea how many promos/winnable games I have lost because my wife just conveniently "decides" to make my computer area her base of operations for the next 50 minutes (and I hear every noise..... from her open mouth chewing to rattling dishes to trying to carry a meaningless conversation..... It's not her fault this game needs absolute concentration, but omfg how it affects your mood and playability)

Combined with the lack of sanctions for trolling, the excessive punishment for verbal toxicity only serves to exacerbate the problem. Think about it: trolls have no reason to flame. They can ruin a match for others without saying a single word. So as it is, the victims of trolling are treated far more harshly than the trolls themselves.

Generally agree, but I think the solution is LESS discipline. Not more. The standard they have set for language as punishment is an unrealizable one, considering the decay of social society in most of the countries in which they operate. Furthermore, Riot itself has recently gotten in trouble for Sexual Preference/Harassment in the workplace, and a "man's workplace" environment. 

If you have no moral fortitude with which to enforce a policy, and your ambition with such policy unenforceable both because it's unachievable to begin with and because your users witness you yourself(Riot) not adhering to the rules themselves, why even try?

Just reduce discipline to a level where it only gets rid of the worst offenders, not "Human Nature."

Then you wouldn't have a comparison of "Troll Discipline vs Verbal Discipline." 

Troll enforcement is abstract and there's no way it never will be. Verbal enforcement is pretty cut and dry (as long as they don't monitor our chat coms). The only way they will ever get equal enforcement...... is when enforcement is at its least.

Less discipline when it comes to policing speech, definitely.
But that will hardly accomplish anything if they don't also crack down on trolling.

Reporting is not completely automated. There is a Rioter involved in every Ban email. The IFS deals with filtering through and cataloging complaints, forwards complaints of hate speech to real people after running through an inventory of known slurs.

And any final Discipline does indeed reach a rioter.

For example, if you are a first time offender, your record make look like this:

-221 reports recieved
-89 reports found to be credible
-132 reports found to be fraudulent/lacking
-440 reports made by you

It may have taken 89 games to actually flag discipline, but somewhere around ~80 credible reports on you recieved, a Rioter got involved and began monitoring reports against you.

They then use those chat logs in your discipline report to back their case of punishment. That part is not automated.

(Most of the system is)

------------------------------------

One report is enough to trigger a review. That's true. (not proven, btw. Proof would require us to have access to knowledge we don't have)

Keep in mind..... multiple reports will not report for the same thing:

The initial report from Player 1 may just say "Verbal Abuse" while a secondary report may say "Verbal Abuse + Hate Speech." The first would have only flagged a review of the violation the ticket is saying.... and looked for random word combination violations for Verbal Abuse. The second would flag a review by a real person, as the violation holds a grander scale punishment (skipping steps in the punishment CoC, and going straight to bans)
